img.alt: Doctor or nurse and a student during a medical checkup

div.p: As we continue to work through the details and implications of the state-wide school closure, we want to always update you with the latest information. The following are reminders or new information on topics of interest to many of you.

The Distance for All online learning model is not intended to replace the traditional learning experience. We are following the Oregon Department of Education’s recommended instructional minute expectations. For Kindergarten through 5th grade, we have asked teachers to provide between 45-90 minutes of instruction/instructional material (45 minutes at the primary grades and 90 minutes at the intermediate grades). For 6th through 8th grades, it is about two hours per day (combined for all classes) and up to three hours at the high school (combined for all classes). For families that are looking for additional materials and resources you can access our Supplemental Remote Learning Resources found here: https://www.nclack.k12.or.us/district/page/remote-learning-resources

p.br: Many of our staff are using a Google Phone application to call families during this long-term school closure. When the phone number shows up on your phone it will show “No Caller ID.” During the period of the closure, we encourage you to answer these calls.

At this time, we are planning to maintain the current calendars as published for this school year. This is subject to change with additional governor executive orders. Based on our published calendars, the last day of distance learning will be the following:

div.p: *Students at Sojourner Elementary School and Cascade Heights Public Charter School have slightly different calendars. Please refer to their published school calendars for year-end dates.

The Oregon Department of Education has released guidance to school districts on the grading of students in grades 9-11. All students who demonstrate work at a level of a passing grade by the end of the 2019-2020 school year will receive credit for the course. Students who do not have an opportunity to earn a passing grade by June 12 will receive an incomplete on their report card and on their transcript. Schools will partner with the student and family to create a plan to earn credit over the next year.

p.strong: FBI WARNING ON ONLINE SEXUAL PREDATORS

div.p: Due to current school closings, many students have an increased online presence and could be in a position that puts them at an inadvertent risk. The FBI (Federal Bureau of Investigation) is seeking to warn parents, educators, caregivers, and children about the dangers of online sexual exploitation and signs of child abuse. Here is a link to a recent press release from the FBI on this subject: https://www.fbi.gov/news/pressrel/press-releases/school-closings-due-to-covid-19-present-potential-for-increased-risk-of-child-exploitation
We are still working on developing solutions to the following issues while maintaining student, family, and staff safety:

li.p: Collection of student materials from school and the returning of district materials to the school

div.p: We plan to continue to update you weekly or as needed. Thank you again for your patience and understanding. We miss our students and send you all the best.

p.span: As we finish up our fourth week since we have seen our students and staff in our schools, we want to provide you this update on the state of various services and processes happening in our district. We hope that this email finds your family healthy and safe.

div.p: During the week of April 13, teachers will begin to provide instruction and assignments to students and will continue until the last scheduled day of the school year. You may find the district calendars on our website for individual levels and schools. Please note that the 2020-21 school year calendars are also included on this page.

p.span: At-home learning will look different for each grade level and subject. However, teachers will not be delivering live instruction or scheduling class meeting times. We know that every home has different needs, including those of our teachers who may also be parents and caregivers of family members in their homes. As parents, you may be dealing with internet access issues, balancing work schedules and also trying to meet the needs of one or more children in your home. Therefore, learning and accessing instruction will be done through recorded video, reading assignments, audio or podcast assignments, and Google classroom. There may also be some traditional pen/paper assignments for certain circumstances. More information will come from your child´s individual teacher(s). However, please be assured that students can do their work in a time and place that works for your home.

div.p: This week, we delivered almost 6,000 Chromebooks laptops to families. Here is a short video highlighting efforts by our technology and transportation departments.
If you have not received the email or phone message about your students' needs for Chromebook laptops, you can complete the form request by clicking HERE.

p.span: Unfortunately, we will NOT have enough Internet Hotspots to meet the number of requests. Fortunately, there are other options for free Internet access. Here are some new options for families:

li.p: Free hotspots: Please check with your cell phone carrier. All the major cellular vendors: Verizon, AT&T, Sprint, and T-Mobile have offered free Hotspots.

p.span: Most Internet providers are waiving late fees and suspending data usage limits due to COVID-19. Check out your specific company for more information:

li.p: Comcast basic internet is free for low income customers for 60 days and $9.99/month after that: www.internetessentials.com/Apply

Xfinity WiFi Free For Everyone: Xfinity WiFi hotspots located in businesses and outdoor locations across the country will be available to anyone who needs them for free – including non-Xfinity Internet subscribers. For a map of Xfinity WiFi hotspots, visit www.xfinity.com/wifi. Once at a hotspot, consumers should select the “xfinitywifi” network name in the list of available hotspots and then launch a browser.

p.span: If you received one of our district hotspots and are able to secure your own through your cell phone provider or other means and no longer need your district-issued device, please call our technology Chromebook hotline number at (503)353-6210 to arrange for it to be returned and deployed to a family on our waiting list.
If none of these options work for you and you still have a need for internet access, please complete the form above if you have not already. We will continue to explore options.

Many families have paid for activities that were canceled due to the statewide closure. The Oregon School Activities Association (OSAA) announced this week that all Spring sports and activities have been canceled. Spring athletic fees will be reimbursed. In the coming weeks staff will create a process and refund these specific fees and any other payments that are within the district´s control.

The 211 Infoline is a statewide resource to navigate families to needed resources. In partnership with the Oregon Health Authority (OHA), 211 Info has activated a statewide call center where people can call to receive current information about COVID-19.

Beginning Wednesday, April 15th and continuing each Wednesday during the school closure Milwaukie High, Putnam High, and Alder Creek Middle schools will offer a weekly meal service that consists of five breakfasts and five lunches. Wednesdays will be the only service days at these locations. Please plan to be asked your name, telephone number, and the grade level of your student(s) when collecting your weekly meals. Children under the age of 5 will still be provided meals. If you cannot collect weekly meals on Wednesdays daily meal service will continue to be provided at our other service locations, Clackamas High School, Linwood, Lewelling, Ardenwald, View Acres, Bilquist, Riverside, Oak Grove, and Whitcomb Elementary Schools from 9:00-10:30 am.

strong.span: COLLECTION OF STUDENT PERSONAL ITEMS AND RETURN OF DISTRICT ITEMS

p.span: Many students have personal items that were left in schools that need to be retrieved. In addition, many students have district property such as library books, musical instruments, and athletic equipment that need to be returned. We will work in the coming weeks to develop a process for each school to allow families to retrieve personal items and return district property. Your school will communicate that process when it is available. This would also include items such as yearbooks that would have normally been distributed this spring. More information to come.

Our high school principals are reaching out to some of their seniors this week to get their input and insight regarding graduation. We will then use that information to craft a survey to senior parents. Today, it seems unlikely that we will host traditional graduation ceremonies in June. Therefore, we are exploring other options for later in the summer (assuming large group gatherings are allowed then). More information to come on this topic in future communications.

div.p: North Clackamas Schools will be participating in a national movement called Be the Light. The movement asks high schools to turn on their stadium lights at 8:20 p.m. (20:20 military time) to honor the Class of 2020. Beginning this Friday through June 12 stadium lights in North Clackamas will be turned on for 5 minutes. The lights are a message of hope and support. We want students to know they are in our hearts and minds. We encourage community members to join the movement by turning on their front porch lights at the same time to show their support.

p.span: We thought it important for you to know that the NCSD School Board voted unanimously at its April 9 meeting to officially suspend the search for a new Superintendent and accept Matt Utterback’s offer to defer his retirement plans for another year. The Board extended their appreciation to Mr. Utterback for providing consistent leadership during this time of uncertainty and unprecedented community need.
As always this communication and a variety of additional resources are always available on our district website at www.nclack.k12.or.us.
